data.title: Goto declaration should store current cursor in navigation history
data.body:
Steps to Reproduce:
1. Invoke editor.action.goToDeclaration
2. Invoke workbench.action.navigateBack
The cursor should go back to the exact spot where it was before the jump. Instead, it goes one sport further back...

data.title: Disable format of plain text in HTML
data.body:
Hello,
I work with OctoberCMS, and the html files are as following:
![](https://i.imgur.com/fMSHZKC.png)

Those lines above the `==` need to be under eachother if you want it to work. But if I format (even without any extensions!) this happens:
![](https://i.imgur.com/mdqv7dv.png)
Unfortunately this causes the code to break.

Is it possible to prevent this plain text from getting formatted inside html files?

data.title: Allow to minimize VS Code to tray

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Even though VSC is launching very fast (clean install, 3s on my machine) it is not instant like the classic sublime text or N++.
If we could keep the editor loaded all the time we would get faster file opening times by sacrificing ram.

Therefore I suggest addition of editor tray and "Minimize to tray"/"Close to tray" options.
The editor would be then closed by right clicking the tray icon and selecting "close" option there.

data.title: Extension tests failing on Linux since 1.5 was released
data.body:
When the 1.5 release went out our tests on Linux all started failing. Everything still works on Windows/Max, but on Linux the tests seem to just fail.

This build was just before the 1.5 release and worked fine:

https://travis-ci.org/Dart-Code/Dart-Code/builds/158524709

Then I pushed a simple change to the README and updated the version number in package.json and the tests now fail to run:

https://travis-ci.org/Dart-Code/Dart-Code/jobs/158543037

``` text
11.12s$ npm test --silent
### VS Code Extension Test Run ###
Current working directory: /home/travis/build/Dart-Code/Dart-Code
Downloading VS Code into "/home/travis/build/Dart-Code/Dart-Code/.vscode-test" from: https://vscode-update.azurewebsites.net/1.5.0/linux-x64/stable
Running extension tests: /home/travis/build/Dart-Code/Dart-Code/.vscode-test/VSCode-linux-x64/code /home/travis/build/Dart-Code/Dart-Code/out/test --extensionDevelopmentPath=/home/travis/build/Dart-Code/Dart-Code --extensionTestsPath=/home/travis/build/Dart-Code/Dart-Code/out/test
Failed to execute tests: Error: spawn EACCES
Tests exited with code: -1
```

I've tried a few rebuilds since, but they all fail the same - I don't think it's even started to run the tests. The same code is building fine on Mac and Windows.

I'll try and do some debugging tomorrow (it's late here and I don't have a Linux box to hand), but thought it was worth raising this in case others could repro or wanted to investigate.

data.title: Issue with using Tab or Enter when performing short hand code (not for sure if short hand is the way to put it but it works)
data.body: - VSCode Version: Code 1.5.0 (4fc690be310dd02e0ab6529c0b9bf348a8b26a19, 2016-09-08T09:09:27.395Z) - OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.10586 Steps to Reproduce: 1. Type Table and hit tab 2. Type tr and hit tab What used to happen is the cursor would be placed in between the tr tags `cursor would be here` after hitting the tab key on a tr or td tag. Since the last update, it now goes to the end of the line which isn't too aggravating if you have just the tr and nothing else. It become aggravating when you have something like this: `` Let's say you forgot to change or want to add some styles to the td tag. Steps to Reproduce: 1. Go into the td tag and hit space just after the 'd' in 'td' 2. Type 'style' and hit tab Instead of placing the cursor inside the style tag `style="cursor goes here"`, you end up with: `CURSOR IS WAY OVER HERE`

data.title: OSX: ctrl+n/ctrl+p no longer cycle list item selection in command palette
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.5.0
- OS Version: OS X El Capitan 10.11.6

Before updating to VSCode 1.5.0, I used `ctrl+n`/`ctrl+p` to cycle through the list of suggestions in the command palette menu, identical to how those bindings behave in an IntelliSense/autocomplete menu within the editor. These bindings no longer work in the command palette despite working as expected in autocomplete menus within the editor; instead, they move the cursor in the command palette text input to the start (`ctrl+p`) or end (`ctrl+n`) of the text input itself.

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open command palette with `cmd+p`.
2. Attempt to cycle to next item of list using `ctrl+n` keybinding. Observe no list cursor movement.
3. Attempt to cycle to previous item of list using `ctrl+p` keybinding. Observe no list cursor movement.
4. Enter any text in command palette input field and leave text cursor at the right edge of input.
5. Attempt to cycle to previous item of list using `ctrl+p` keybinding. Observe the text cursor jump to start of the input field.
6. Attempt to cycle to next item of list using `ctrl+n` keybinding. Observe the text cursor jump to the end of input field.

data.title: OSX: Keybinding for cmd+e is wrongly mapped to "actions.find" instead of "workbench.action.quickOpen"
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.5.0
- OS Version: OSX El Capitan

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open keybinding preferences in OSX, find "cmd+e"
2. L148 reads `{ "key": "cmd+e",                 "command": "actions.find" },`

In Linux, the equivalent "ctrl+e" has the following mappings:

```
{ "key": "ctrl+e",                "command": "workbench.action.quickOpen" },
{ "key": "ctrl+e",                "command": "workbench.action.quickOpenNavigateNext",
                                     "when": "inQuickOpen" },
```

In OSX, `cmd+e` was formerly (prior to 1.5.0) mapped to these same bindings as Linux's`ctrl+e`.

**Workaround for users:**
1. Go to the application menu _Code => Preferences => Keyboard Shortcuts_
2. Paste the following into the keybindings.json file:

```
    {
        "key": "cmd+e",
        "command": "workbench.action.quickOpen"
    },
    {
        "key": "cmd+e",
        "command": "workbench.action.quickOpenNavigateNext",
        "when": "inQuickOpen"
    }
```

data.title: Update downloads but fails to apply
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.4.0
- OS Version: macOS 10.11.6

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open vscode, wait for it to download 1.5 update
2. Click "Update now" in the dialogue that appears once the update is ready
3. vscode reopens, but it's still version 1.4.0.  It will detect the update again and redownload it, then repeat.

data.title: User snippets are in the wrong order
Add configuration to remove group labels from "Opened Editors" view

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
It would be nice to see something like a `workbench.editor.unifyOpenFilesList` option that is false by default, but if true, will have the older behavior of a single list, that updates the current pane on clicking.

If the setting is set while `workbench.editor.showTabs` is `true`, then it should add the file to the tab-group, and set it to current.  When showTabs is `false`, it should update the current pane to the selected file (old behavior).

---

Per #11612, and #9097, The following options are available for getting close to the pre-tabs behavior... The above mentioned feature would close the loop on this.

```
"explorer.openEditors.visible": 10,
"workbench.action.closeEditorsInGroup" :true,
"workbench.editor.showTabs": false, 
"workbench.editor.enablePreview": false,
"workbench.editor.enablePreviewFromQuickOpen": false,
```

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.5.0
- OS Version: OSX

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Navigate to extension viewlet, click on any extension which contributes to the settings
2. The `Settings` section shows setting name and description without a default value

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/876920/18364767/6c3216d8-75c4-11e6-9b55-720c42dacc09.png)

The contribution section looks amazing and IMO it would be better if people can see default values for options there.

data.title: TypeScript: nested generic detail incorrect
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.4.0
- OS Version: latest
- TS version: latest 2 beta

Steps to Reproduce:

Given:

``` ts
type Foo<T> = { foo: T };
const y = <X, T>(t: Foo<T>) => t;
y({ foo: 2 })
```

When I inspect `y` by hovering over it, I expect it to have the type: `<{}, number>(t: Foo<number>) => number`, but it actually has the type `<{}, number>(t: Foo<{}, number>) => number`.

Where is `Foo` shown to receive more generics that it has asked for?

data.title: Icon & indentation visual issues in file list after upgrading to 1.5 on OSX
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.5.0
- OS Version: OSX 10.11.6

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Had the popular [vscode-icons](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=robertohuertasm.vscode-icons) extension installed in version immediately prior to 1.5
2. Upgraded VSCode to 1.5.0
3. Now, once I select an icon theme like Seti it appears there are conflicts with the old icon set from the vscode-icons extension. I tried uninstalling the extension, terminating all instances of VSCode and restarting, but still see artifacts as you can see below:
   - The **Open Editors** window uses the old icons, but the actual project shows the new icon set from the included Seti theme
   - The colored folders still appear in the project view... the preview of the Seti them seemed to not have folders... this look to come from the old extension
   - Indentation of items seems off... the files in the root of the project are nested under folders
   - Indentation of items within folders seems to be extremely duped... for instance in below image, the file `build.ts` resides in `/build/gulp/tasks` while `buildBarrel.ts` resides in `/build/gulp`

![2016-09-08_15-41-32](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2068657/18364157/5660e8b8-75db-11e6-888d-ae8749863474.png)

Tried finding a place where icons were cached, but can't find anything... searched the `/users/[]/.vscode/*` folder... ensuring the extension was really gone which it is.

data.title: Applying Icon theme BSD
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.5.0
- OS Version: Windows 10 Enterprise version 1511 , OS build 10586.494

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Go to file -> preferences -> Icon Theme
2. Try to apply the Seti Theme

It appeared to apply the theme, but I immediately got a BSD with Bad Pool Header. I do appear to have a tsc compiler mismatch version with a globally installed version, but I'm not sure that could be related in any way.

After rebooting the system and trying again it worked without a BSD. There could be an issue related to having it(vscode) open, doing the update and then having it re-open after the update and then doing this. I wish I could provide more information. Also curious if this happens to anyone else.

data.title: Regression: Unable to bypass ssl verification any more for corp firewall
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.5
- OS Version: 10.11.6

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Install a transparent man-in-the-middle firewall with a self signed cert and be sure that all traffic is being intercepted.
2. Install VSCode 1.4.
3. Notice that VSCode can't update extensions due to MITM.
4. Set http.proxyStrictSSL=false
5. Notice that VSCode can now update extensions or search extensions, etc.
6. Upgrade to 1.5
7. Notice that VSCode can no longer speak to the internet when trying to search for an extension
